title: What's the difference between atomic number and proton number? - Quora

response.answer_text: I once heard that there is a Chinese restaurant named the George Ferguson restaurant, owned by a Chinese man of that name. When coming through Ellis Island the guy in front of him declared his name to get George Ferguson, and the next guy said, “Sam Ting.” Yes, the number of protons is the "Sam Ting” as the atomic number.

That’s pretty much the same. Hydrogen has atomic number 1 because it has 1 proton in the nucleus (with possibly few neutrons, too, like for Deuterium or Tritium). Carbon is number 6, with 6 protons, and a variety of possible neutron configurations, including the famous  isotope.

There is no difference. Atomic number and proton number refers to the same thing: the number of protons found in the nucleus of an element. The atomic number uniquely identifies a chemical element i.e. the atomic number is unique to a particular element.
The atomic number of an element is the number of protons and neutrons combined. The proton number is simply the number of protons each element has.
There is no difference. Because in the PTE the elements are ordered according to their amount of protons. atomic number =! proton number
